description: The area of land drained by a river system.
A ridge of high land that forms the boundary between two drainage basins.
The origin or starting point of a river.
The point at which a river flows into a much larger body of water – an ocean, sea or lake.
A river or stream flowing into a larger river or lake.
The point where a tributary stream/river joins a main river.
The pattern of a main river and its tributaries within a drainage basin.

A measure of the efficiency of a stream’s shape – that is, the crosssectional area divided by the wetted perimeter. The higher the ratio, the more efficient the stream and the smaller the frictional loss. The ideal form is semi-circular.
The total length of the cross-section at the interface between a channel bed and the stream water that occupies it.
The speed of a river’s water, measured in metres per second.
The amount of water passing a specific point at a given time (the volume times the velocity). It is measured in cubic metres per second.
The frictional force of a river bed. A rough bed (with boulders, pebbles, potholes) exerts more friction than a smooth channel.
A geographical model that suggests how a river’s characteristics change from the source to the mouth of the river.
The total length of all the streams and rivers in a drainage basin divided by the total area of the drainage basin.
A longitudinal section of the course of a river drawn along the river from source to mouth.
The flow of water through permeable rock.
The flow of water through the soil under gravity.
Water flowing over the surface under the influence of gravity. It occurs when the soil is saturated.
A system unconnected to other entities. It has no inputs from, or outputs to, elsewhere.
The movement of water between air, land and sea.
The spaces in and on earth which hold water across all its states of matter.
A rock that allows water to move through it, such as a layer of sandstone.
The movement of water between stores in the hydrological cycle.
The process in which a liquid turns to a vapour.
The process by which water vapour changes into water droplets.
Water that falls to the Earth from the atmosphere. It is part of the hydrological cycle. Forms include rain, snow, sleet, hail, dew and frost.
Rainfall and snow falling directly into a river or stream.
The movement of water within the river channel.
When the soil is so full of water that it cannot absorb any more.
The initial movement of water from the surface into the upper level of the soil.
The downward, vertical movement of water within soil or rock.
Surfaces that allow water to pass through, either due to porosity (large volume of pore spaces) or due to being pervious (having joints and cracks/fissures).
Surfaces that do not allow water to pass through.
The upper level of groundwater saturation in permeable rocks.
Water stored underground in a permeable rock, e.g. chalk or sandstone.
The precipitation that is collected and stored by vegetation.
The loss of moisture from vegetation into the atmosphere.
A combination of the processes of evaporation and transpiration.
A dry area with limited vegetation. They can be either hot or cold. Characteristics common to all these regions include irregular rainfall of less than 250 mm per year.
The resistance encountered when one body moves relative to another body with which it is in contact.

The erosive force exerted by water alone, such as the sheer force of river water removing loose material from the bed and banks of the river. It is particularly effective on jointed rocks, especially during storm conditions.
The wearing away of the river bed and banks by the river’s load hitting them repeatedly.

The process by which particles of rock being transported by a river are rounded and become smaller in size by being struck against one another. Particles near the shoreline become smaller and more rounded due to more frequent attrition.
The process by which the minerals in a rock, notably calcium ions, are dissolved in acid water. Solution is one of the processes of erosion.
Downward erosion occurring in the upper course of the river, where the river cuts down into its bed, deepening the valley.
Sideways erosion of a river bank that results in its valley getting wider.
The particles of sediment and dissolved matter carried along by a river.
When the smallest and lightest particles of a river’s load (silt and clay) are carried in suspension by the moving water.

When larger particles of a river’s load (sand, gravel, very small stones) are transported in a series of ‘hops’ or bounces along the river bed. It is the means by which bedload (material that is too heavy to be carried in suspension) is transported downstream.
The sliding or rolling of sediment along the river bed or sea floor.

The laying down of material carried by rivers or the sea because of a reduction of velocity or discharge (both causing a loss of energy), often caused by increased friction with vegetation or coarse particles.
Material rolled along the river bed.
Material deposited by rivers in a channel or on a floodplain.
The movement of a river’s load by the processes of traction, saltation, suspension and solution.

Rivers in upland areas contain large boulders that can erode the bed rapidly when the river is in flood. This results in the river cutting downward into its bed by vertical erosion to form steep V-shaped valleys.
Projecting areas of high ground in the upper course of a river that interlink.
A circular depression in a river bed formed by the abrasive action of rock particles caught up in vortices in turbulent river flow.
A steep fall of river water where its course is suddenly and significantly interrupted.
A narrow, steep-sided valley that may or may not have a river at the bottom.
Where very thin alternating bands of hard and soft rock cross the course of a river, creating an uneven river bed and a zone of turbulent water.
A pothole which forms at the base of a waterfall due to erosion.
A winding turn in river channel. It is found in the lower course along the long profile.
A steep slope that may be found on the outer bend of a meander.
The gentle slope found on the inside bank of a river meander.
A thin piece of land between two successive outer bank meanders, likely to be eroded in the future to form an oxbow lake.
A curved lake found on the floodplain of a river. Oxbows are caused by the loops of meanders being cut off at times of flood and the river subsequently adopting a shorter course.
The area of periodic flooding along the course of a river valley.
The sub-division of a river into several channels, caused by deposition of sediment as small islands in the main channel.
A flat, low-lying deposit of sediment that is found at a river’s mouth.
The total amount of sediment a river can carry.
The maximum size of particle a river can carry.
A discharge great enough to cause a body of water to overflow its channel and submerge the surrounding area.
A large but temporary increase in channel discharge.

An extended period of dry weather leading to conditions of extreme dryness. An absolute one is a period of at least 15 consecutive days with less than 0.2 mm of rainfall. A partial one is a period of at least 29 consecutive days during which the average daily rainfall does not exceed 0.2 mm.

The removal of forest cover or destruction of forest for timber, fuel or charcoal burning, or clearing for agriculture and extractive industries such as mining. It can be complete or partial. It causes fertile soil to be blown away or washed into rivers, leading to soil erosion, drought, flooding and loss of wildlife.
Improving water quality to make it acceptable for a particular end use, such as human consumption or irrigation.
The land above and surrounding wells drilled into an aquifer.
A United States scientific agency that studies the landscape of the USA, its natural resources, and the natural hazards that threaten it.

Any coastal or river protection scheme that involves altering the natural environment with concrete, stone, steel, metal, etc. – for example the use of sea walls, gabions, groynes and revetments. Artificial structures are built in order to protect the natural environment from erosion.
Any form of coastal or river protection that involves the use of natural means, e.g. sand dunes, saltmarshes, tree planting and/or beach replenishment.
Reducing the amount of runoff in a drainage basin through actions such as preservation of natural water stores.
The grazing of natural pastures at stocking intensities above the livestock carrying capacity.
The practice of allowing certain areas, such as wetlands and floodplains, to be flooded to a greater extent.
The segregation of land use into different areas for each type of use.
The regulations and policies that govern the oversight of surface and groundwater resources within the area of a river catchment.
A natural drainage method for the drainage of surface water to nearby watercourses in urban areas in particular.
The suitability of water to sustain various uses or processes. Any use will have certain requirements for the physical, chemical or biological characteristics of the water.
Contamination of the environment.

These substances allow short-wave radiation to pass through the atmosphere and reach the Earth’s surface, but they absorb some of the outgoing long-wave radiation thereby heating the Earth’s atmosphere.
The depletion of oxygen from water in streams and rivers due to increased levels of nitrates (from fertilisers) or phosphates (from detergents).
An average level of the sea, between the high water mark and low water mark.
The circular or elliptical movement of water near the surface of the sea.
A wooden or concrete barrier built at right angles to a beach in order to block the movement of material along the beach by longshore drift.

The movement of material along a beach by wave action. When a wave breaks obliquely (at an angle to the beach), pebbles are carried up the beach in the direction of the wave (swash). The wave returns to the sea (backwash) at right angles to the beach (direction of steepest slope), carrying material with it.
The movement of material up the beach in the direction of the prevailing wind.
The movement of water back down the beach due to the effect of gravity.
The distance of open water over which wind can blow to create waves. The greater the fetch, the more potential power waves have when they hit the coast.
A wave with a long wave length and a low height. These waves help to build up beaches by deposition.
A wave with a high height and a short wave length, which helps erode beach materials and cliffs.

The way in which a wave changes shape and loses speed as it comes into contact with the sea bed. If refraction is complete, waves break parallel to the coastline. If refraction is not complete, longshore drift occurs.
A point of land projecting into the sea; also known as a cape or a promontory.
A wide, open, curving indentation of the sea.
A gently sloping rock surface found at the base of a coastal cliff. It is covered by water at high tide but is exposed at low tide. It is formed by the erosion (by waves) of a former cliff face.

A depositional feature – a long ridge of sand or pebbles running parallel to a coastline that is submerged at high tide. Some develop offshore when waves disturb sediments on the sea bed and form them into a submarine ridge, while others form from the development of a spit across the whole of a small bay.
A coastal body of shallow saltwater, usually with limited access to the sea. The term is normally used to describe a shallow sea area cut off by a coral reef or a bar.

A ridge of sand or shingle connected to the land at one end and the open sea at the other end. It is formed by the interruption of longshore drift due to wave refraction, river currents, secondary winds and/or changes in the shape of the coastline.
A bar or ridge that links an island to the mainland.
A mound or ridge of wind-drifted sand common on coasts and in deserts. In coastal areas, sand is trapped by vegetation, notably sea couch grass and marram grass, to form stable them.
A relatively straight coastline in which the relief and geology are parallel to the coast.
A coastline in which the relief and geology are at right angles to the coastline.
A natural event that puts people, property and livelihoods at risk.
A region of very low atmospheric pressure in tropical regions. These storms cause large amounts of damage annually.
A large and unusual wave in the water generated by a submarine earthquake, volcanic eruption or landslide.
measure taken to prevent coastal erosion and/or flooding. To reduce erosion, several different forms of coastal protection are used. These can be divided into hard engineering and soft engineering.
The wearing away of coastlines by moving agents, such as waves and wind, to create coastal features such as cliffs and wave-cut platforms.
A form of managing natural processes that involves taking no action but allowing natural processes to operate without any human intervention.
When the coastline is allowed to retreat (erode) in certain areas where the population density or the value of land is low, so that nature takes its course.
A scale to measure the intensity, windspeed and likely damage caused by tropical cyclones.
Living organisms that may form large reefs. They provide a habitat for a wide diversity of living organisms.
A salt-tolerant forest of trees and shrubs that grows in the tidal estuaries and coastal zones of tropical areas.
To capture and remove CO2 from the Earth’s atmosphere and to store it permanently.
An area of coastline or ocean that is given some form of protection or conservation, e.g. activities such as fishing, mining or drilling may be banned or restricted.
The pressure at any point on the Earth’s surface that is due to the weight of the air above it; it decreases as altitude increases.

A form of precipitation in which drops of water fall to the Earth’s surface from clouds. The drops are formed by the accumulation of fine droplets that condense from water vapour in the air. The condensation is usually brought about by the rising and subsequent cooling of air.

Water vapour condensed into minute water particles that float in the atmosphere. They are formed by the cooling of air containing water vapour, which generally condenses around tiny dust or ice particles.
The reflectivity of a surface – snow and ice are very reflective, whereas dark surfaces, such as soil, are not.

Measurement of height, usually given in metres above sea level. Temperature
declines, on average, 1°C for every 100 m

The outermost layer of the Earth’s solid surface, consisting of weathered rock, air, water and decaying organic matter overlying the bedrock. It comprises minerals, organic matter (humus) derived from decomposed plants and organisms, living organisms, air and water.

An integrated unit consisting of a community of living organisms (animals and plants) and the physical environment (air, soil, water and climate) that they inhabit. Individual organisms interact with each other and with their habitat.
The management of the human use of natural resources to provide the maximum benefit to current generations while maintaining capacity to meet the needs of future generations.
A document required by law detailing all the impacts on the environment of a construction project above a certain size.
A form of managing natural processes that involves very limited human intervention but may aim at protecting human lives.

Dense forest usually found on or near the equator, where the climate is hot and wet. The vegetation in these regions typically includes a canopy formed by high branches of tall trees that provides shade for lower layers, an intermediate layer of shorter trees, tree roots and lianas, and a ground cover of mosses and ferns.

Rainfall associated with hot climates, resulting from the rising of currents of warm air. Air that has been warmed by the extreme heating of the ground surface rises to great heights and is cooled quickly. The water vapour carried by the air condenses and rain falls heavily.

The quantity of water vapour in a given volume of air, or the ratio of the amount of water vapour in the atmosphere to the maximum amount the air can hold. At dew point the relative humidity is 100 per cent and the air is said to be saturated. Condensation (the conversion of vapour to liquid) may then occur.
A measure of the variety of the Earth’s plant and animal species, of genetic differences within species, and of the ecosystems that support those species.
A large farm or estate where one crop is produced commercially, such as palm oil in Malaysia or tea in Sri Lanka.

Any fuel produced from organic matter, either directly from plants or indirectly from industrial, commercial, domestic or agricultural wastes. For example fossil fuel substitute can be made from a range of crops, including oilseeds, wheat and sugar.
The re-use of nutrients over time. They are recycled between the atmosphere, plants, animals and the soil.
The wearing away and redistribution of the Earth’s soil. It is caused by the action of water, wind and ice, and also by unsustainable methods of agriculture.
The highest discharge of a river flood.
The combination of weather conditions at a particular place over a period of time – usually a minimum of 30 years.
Molten or semi-molten material found beneath the Earth’s surface.
A plate boundary where new material is created and two plates move away from each other, e.g. the North American and European Plates moving away from the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
A plate boundary where two plates meet and the denser oceanic plate subducts/plunges underneath the less dense continental plate. They are associated with creating ocean trenches and fold mountains.
A plate boundary where two plates meet. It may lead to the creation of fold mountains, e.g. the Himalayas.
A plate boundary in which plates move past each other in different directions or at different speeds but no material is destroyed or created. They are associated with earthquake activity.
The gradual increase in the size of the oceans as new material is added to the oceans at constructive plate boundaries/mid-ocean ridges.
The exact point within or on the Earth’s surface where an earthquake occurs.
An earthquake that occurs at a depth of over 70 km beneath the Earth’s surface.
An area where a dense oceanic plate plunges underneath a less-dense continental plate.
An earthquake that occurs up to a depth of 70 km.
The point on the Earth’s surface immediately above an earthquake’s focus.
A wave-like motion through the Earth caused by an earthquake, volcanic eruption or landslide.
A seismic wave that travels through the Earth’s interior.
A seismic wave at the Earth’s surface. Love waves cause the ground to move sideways, and Rayleigh waves cause the ground to move up and down.
The fastest type of seismic wave, which causes the ground to shake.
A secondary or shear wave is a seismic wave that travels through solids, with an undulating/wavelike movement (up and down).
A superheated cloud of volcanic ash, cinder, tephra and other fragments. It can reach temperatures of over 700°C and is capable of travelling at speeds of over 500 km/hour.
A mudflow consisting of volcanic ash, rain and/or snow.
A low-angle volcano formed of very hot, runny, basaltic lava.
A steep-sided volcano made of fragments of volcanic materials.
A cone-shaped volcano formed of viscous, sticky lava.
A volcano that is currently erupting or has recently erupted and is likely to erupt again.
A volcano that has not erupted for a long time, but could erupt in the future.
A volcano that erupted in the past but will not erupt in the future.
A bowl-shaped depression at the summit of a volcano, formed by a volcanic eruption.
A fracture on the summit of a volcano through which lava can be ejected.
An underground reservoir of molten magma.
A smaller cone found on the side of a volcano’s main cone.
A slow-moving flow of molten lava, typically moving at 1–10 km/hour and with temperatures of over 700°C.
All volcanic fragments ejected into the air during an eruption.
Very small, hard, jagged material of volcanic origin. It is the most frequent and widespread volcanic hazard.
A fragment of rock measuring over 64 mm in diameter that is erupted in a solid condition.
A gas given off by an active volcano, including water vapour, carbon dioxide, sulphur dioxide, hydrogen sulphide, nitrogen, methane and carbon monoxide.
A scale to measure the magnitude of an earthquake. The scale is logarithmic, so an earthquake of 5.0 magnitude is ten times greater than one of 4.0 magnitude.
A scale that measures the effects of an earthquake based on its intensity of shaking and the observed damage.
A scale that measures the amount of energy released by an earthquake.

A measure of the amount of volcanic material ejected in an eruption, the height the material is thrown into the atmosphere, and how long the eruption lasts. The scale is logarithmic, so a VEI 6.0 is ten times greater than a VEI 5.0.
A volcano with a Volcanic Explosivity Index of 8.0, i.e. an eruption of over 1000 km3.
The expansion of sea water as its temperature increases.
The geological era lasting from about 2.6 million years ago to around 11,700 years ago, characterised by multiple glacial (cold) periods and interglacial (warm) periods.
The most recent geological epoch, beginning 11,700 years ago.
The warm phase during an ice age, i.e. when ice sheets and glaciers retreat.
The cold phase in an ice age, i.e. when ice sheets and glaciers advance.

Some atmospheric gases, such as water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide, are greenhouse gases. This means that they allow short-wave radiation to pass through the atmosphere and reach the Earth’s surface, but they absorb some of the outgoing long-wave radiation thereby heating the Earth’s atmosphere. This is a natural process.
A non-renewable resource, such as coal, oil or natural gas, formed from the remains of prehistoric carbon compound- or hydrocarbon-containing materials.
The production of crops and livestock, aquaculture and forest products, e.g. rice, fish and cotton, for food and non-food products.

The additional heat that is trapped as a result of the increased levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. This is largely as a result of human activities and is causing the world climate to become hotter and more extreme.
A critical threshold when even a small change can have dramatic effects and cause a disproportionately large response.

term: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
description: The UN process for reaching an agreement to limit dangerous climate change. Its main objective is the stabilisation of greenhouse emissions to prevent dangerous human-caused climate change.
An international agreement that aimed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and the presence of atmospheric greenhouse gases.

A legally binding international treaty on climate change. It was adopted by 196 Parties in 2015 and came into force in 2016. Its aim is to keep the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels.
Methods of learning to live with climate change, e.g. sea walls and malaria tablets.
Measures used to prevent or limit global climate change, e.g. burning less fossil fuel and/or planting more trees.
The largest population that the resources of a given environment can support.
A person who studies human populations.
A prediction of the future population, usually based on current and past trends.
The number of deaths of children under five years of age per thousand live births per year.
When a country’s fertility rate declines to or below the replacement level, but the population continues to grow because of its age structure.
The number of live births per thousand population in a year.
The number of deaths per thousand population in a year.
The difference between the birth rate and death rate. If it is positive, it is termed natural increase. If it is negative, it is known as natural decrease.
The difference between the numbers of immigrants and emigrants in a year.
The number of immigrants per thousand population entering a receiving country in a year.
The number of emigrants per thousand population leaving a country of origin in a year.
The number of live births per 1000 women aged 15–44 years in a given year.
The average number of children born to a woman in a country during her lifetime.
A fertility rate of 2.1 children per woman is required to maintain a population at its current level. Below this level, a population will eventually decline.
A policy that is encouraging and supportive of increasing the fertility rate.
A policy that is discouraging and unsupportive of increasing fertility.
A model illustrating the historical shift of birth and death rates from high to low levels in a population.
The average number of years a newborn infant can expect to live under current mortality levels.
The composition of a population, the most important elements of which are age and sex (gender).
A bar chart, arranged vertically, that shows the distribution of a population by age and gender.
The ratio of the number of people aged under 15 years and over 64 years to those in the 15–64 age group.
The ratio of the number of people aged 0–14 years to those in the 15–64 age group.
The ratio of the number of people aged 65 and over to those in the 15–64 age group.
The growth in an economy resulting from a change in the age structure of a country’s population.
The idea that there is time to enact policies and encourage behaviours to limit the potential adverse effects of demographic changes.
A person who is forced to flee their home due to human or environmental factors and who crosses an international border into another country.
A facility able to move containers between different modes of transport, with storage space for containers waiting for the next leg of the journey.
The country from which a migration begins.
The country where a migration is completed.
When individuals have a free choice about whether to migrate or not.
When people are made to move against their will due to human or environmental factors.
A negative factor at the place of origin.
A positive factor at the destination.
Money sent back by a migrant to their family in their home community.
The dispersion of a people, originally belonging to one country, around the world.
The definition of a group or individual (by themselves or others) in terms of ethnicity, nationality, language, religion and gender.
An increase in the proportion of people living in urban areas.
The absolute growth of urban areas in population size and/or the physical growth of urban areas.
The very poorest countries.
The growth of residential areas at the edges of urban areas; the movement of people into the suburbs (outer parts of the city).
A residential area found towards the edge of a city and located relatively far from the central areas.
The movement of people away from larger urban areas to smaller urban areas and/or rural settlements.
The increase in population in the inner city of an urban area following a period of urban decline.
The outward movement of economic activity from CBDs and inner cities.
The use of resources to improve the quality of life in a country.
The UN’s development agency working to eradicate poverty. It plays a crucial role in helping countries achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.
The total GNI of a country divided by the total population.
Takes into account variations in the cost of living between countries.
Dishonest or illegal behaviour by people in powerful positions, typically involving bribery.
An increase in real GDP (%) after inflation is taken into account.
The number of deaths of children under one year of age per 1000 live births per year.
The composite UN measure of the disparities between countries, using indicators of health, education and income.

The idea that countries sit on different rungs of a ladder, each associated with a different set of economic activities. As countries develop, they become more capable of producing higher-level goods and services, and move up the ladder.
When a country relies on one or a small number of primary products for most of its export earnings.
The process of being pushed to the edge of economic activity
The productive resources, entrepreneurial capabilities, and production links that together determine a country’s capability to produce goods and services, and enable it to grow and develop.
A significant decline in economic activity brought about by factors such as a global economic shock or by the impact of a major natural hazard.
An economy that undergoes rapid economic growth, usually accompanied by an increase in the standard of living.
The difference in income and quality of life in general between the highest and lowest-income countries in the world.
A country that does not have direct access either to an ocean, or to a sea that is not landlocked.
A country with few investment and trade barriers, which encourages business with other countries.
The effectiveness, transparency and strength of the institutions within a country, such as the police and the courts.
The dominance of lower-income countries by wealthy ones, not by direct political control (as in colonialism), but by economic power and cultural influence.
A theory that blames the relative underdevelopment of the developing world on exploitation by the developed world, first through colonialism and then by neocolonialism.
The social and economic system that relies on the market mechanism to distribute the factors of production (land, labour, capital) in the most efficient way.
The most highly developed region(s) in a country or in the world.
Parts of a country (or the world) outside of the economic core region(s).
The idea that an initial amount of spending or investment causes money to circulate in an economy, bringing a series of economic benefits over time.
The practice of shielding a country’s domestic industries from foreign competition by taxing imports.
The gulf between those who have ready access to computers and the internet and those who do not.
The percentage of the total population that use the internet.
Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

The UN’s 17 Sustainable Development Goals with their 169 targets were adopted by UN Member States in 2015. The overall objectives were to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure all people enjoy peace and prosperity.
An indicator that uses 58 performance indicators across 11 categories to score and rank countries around the globe on climate change performance, environmental health and ecosystem vitality.

The preservation and protection of the natural environment over time. It involves appropriate practices and policies to meet present-day needs without compromising the availability of resources in the future.
An economic system based on the reuse and regeneration of materials and products, especially as a means of continuing production in a sustainable way.
The wellbeing of people and the communities they live in.
Conducting economic activities in a way that preserves and promotes long-term economic wellbeing.
A scheme in London that has significantly reduced the number of older, high-polluting vehicles entering the city’s urban area. (ULEZ)

term: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
description: The UN’s commission that deals with trade, investment and development issues, assisting countries to integrate into the world economy on an equitable basis. It is based in Geneva, Switzerland.

The giving of resources (money, food, goods, technology, etc.) by one country or organisation to another, lower-income country. The objective is to improve the economy and quality of life in that country.
Foreign aid that must be spent in the country providing the aid (the donor country).
Aid supplied by a donor country whereby the level of technology and the skills required to service it are properly suited to the conditions in the receiving country.
Money owed by a country to another country, to private creditors (e.g. commercial banks), or to international agencies such as the World Bank or IMF.
The proportion of a country’s GDP required to pay off its debts each year.
The cancellation of debts owed by developing nations to developed countries or to institutions such as the World Bank, in order to allow the government to shift funds toward social development.
Tiny loans and financial services to help people, mostly women, start businesses and escape poverty.
A form of business that seeks to profit from investments that generate social improvements and serve a broader human development purpose.
A country made up of a group of islands, interconnecting waters, and other natural features that are closely interrelated.
The economic sector that exploits raw materials. Farming, fishing, forestry and mining make up most jobs in this sector.
The economic sector that manufactures primary materials into finished products.
The economic sector that provides services to people and to businesses.
The economic sector that uses high technology to provide information and expertise to all sectors of an economy.
The full sequence of activities needed to turn raw materials into a finished product.
A production process where labour costs are high compared to expenditure on capital (factory, machinery, etc.).
The most labour-intensive and generally the smallest scale of agriculture, where the produce is consumed entirely or mainly by the family who work the land or tend the livestock.
The transformation in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries of first the UK and then other European countries and the USA from agricultural into industrial nations.
A country that since the 1960s has experienced very rapid growth in manufacturing industry.
A country where the tertiary sector dominates employment and where considerable deindustrialisation has occurred.
The replacement of human or animal forms of power by a mechanical system such as a tractor in agriculture.
The long-term absolute decline of employment in manufacturing.
A high level of investment in plant and machinery compared to labour.
Investment in physical capital in other countries by transnational corporations.
The ease with which a place can be reached. An area with high accessibility will generally have a well-developed transport network and be centrally located.
Where the finished product is heavier than the weight of the raw materials required to manufacture it.
Similar to an industrial estate, but dominated by tertiary activities.
A system of intermodal freight transport using standard international containers.
A port that has the depth of water, natural or dredged, and the technology to handle very large ocean-going ships, particularly ultra-large container ships.
A vessel with a capacity of at least 14,000 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units).
The increasing interdependence of the world economically, culturally and politically.
A city that is an important nodal point in the global economic system. These cities are major financial and decision-making centres.
Divides production into different skills and tasks that are spread across countries rather than taking place within a single country.
The stages involved in manufacturing a finished product (commodity) for sale to consumers. These stages may occur in factories in different countries.
The exchange of goods and services between countries.
A group of countries that share trade agreements between each other.
A location where routes converge, allowing for the efficient movement of goods and people. The most important transport hubs are often intermodal.
The spreading of cultural traits from one place to another.
A society in which patterns of consumption are a key basis for personal identity and status differentiation.
An innovation that significantly alters the way that consumers, industries and businesses operate.
A firm that owns or controls productive operations in more than one country through foreign direct investment.
The international trade of intermediate goods and services within the same firm (company).
A phenomenon whereby production is subdivided into activities carried out in different countries.
Travel away from the home environment for leisure, recreation and holidays, or to visit friends and relatives, or for business and professional reasons.
The number of international tourists travelling worldwide or to particular destination countries, usually measured over the course of a year.
Defined by the WTO as expenditure by international inbound visitors, including their payments to national carriers for international transport.
A country from which many people take holidays abroad.
The most popular form of foreign holiday, where travel, accommodation and meals may all be included in the price and booked in advance.
The reasons that people travel. The three major categories are leisure, business and visiting friends and relatives.
The part of the money a tourist pays for a foreign holiday that does not benefit the destination country because it goes elsewhere.
Tourism organised in such a way that its level can be sustained in the future without creating irreparable environmental, social and economic damage to the receiving area.
The environmental impact caused by an individual tourist on holiday in a particular destination.

Visitors seeking a deeper connection to the culture, history and nature of the place they are visiting. They usually stay for longer at a destination while avoiding crowds of tourists and appreciating lesser-visited attractions.
A specialised form of tourism where people experience relatively untouched natural environments, and ensure that their presence does no further damage to these environments.
The cultivation of crops.
The rearing of livestock, such as dairy cattle, sheep and pigs.
Cultivating crops and keeping livestock together on a farm.
Where a relatively small amount of agricultural produce is obtained per hectare of land, so such farms tend to cover large areas of land. Inputs per unit of land are low.
Agriculture characterised by high inputs per unit of land to achieve high yields per hectare.
Agriculture that does not use manufactured chemicals such as chemical fertilisers, pesticides, insecticides and herbicides.

A system where plants are never placed into water, with crops growing suspended in the air. Nutrients are supplied from a mist that is sprayed on to their roots. The entire process is enclosed, so the nutrient mist is able to remain around the plants for longer.
A system where plants may be suspended in nutrient water all the time or fed by an intermittent flow of water.

A system that combines fish farming (aquaculture) with hydroponics. Fish waste is naturally converted into nutrients for plants, while the plants filter the water for the fish. This creates a closed-loop ecosystem.

A situation in which there are recognisable inputs, processes and outputs, such as raw materials, labour, energy and capital. For example, a farm requires a range of inputs, such as labour and energy, before anything else can happen.
An element that is required for a process to take place.
An operation that take places on a farm, such as ploughing and harvesting, or the industrial activities that take place in a factory to make a finished product.
A finished product that is sold to customers or consumed, for example what a farm produces, such as milk, eggs, meat and crops.

The main international indicator used to show variations in global access to food supply. It has limitations – a wholesome diet requires more than just energy and supply figures do not include consumption-level waste (food that is wasted at household, restaurant and retail levels).
The kinds of foods that a person, animal or community habitually eats.
Perfectly edible foodstuffs that are thrown away at the retail and consumer level.
Extremely large data sets analysed computationally to reveal patterns, trends and associations.
Industrialised farming that is typically large scale and capital intensive.
The introduction of high-yielding seeds and modern agricultural techniques in developing countries.

An approach to increasing agricultural production that draws upon the best of the agricultural technologies currently available. It emphasises improved farm management in order to minimise environmental damage from external inputs and benefits farmers and marginal areas bypassed by the original Green Revolution.
A facility able to move containers between different modes of transport, with storage space for containers waiting for the next leg of the journey.
The distance food travels from the farm where it is produced to the plate of the final consumer.
The application of techniques to control the growth and harvesting of animal and vegetable products.
The ratio of agricultural inputs to outputs.
The temperature (low or high) beyond which a plant is unable to grow to a healthy state.
Supplying dry land with water by systems of ditches or by more advanced means.
Distinct levels of investment in and use of agricultural technology, resulting in an increase in agricultural productivity.
The ways in which land is or can be owned. In the past inheritance laws have had a huge impact on the average size of farms.

Pre-harvest food losses from: not planting a crop, or at least not the desired crop; changing crops due to weather; extreme weather reducing or wiping out a crop before harvest; increased predation, pests and/or diseases resulting from climate change.
When all people at all times have access to sufficient, safe, nutritious food to maintain a healthy and active life.
A place where stocks of food, typically basic provisions and non-perishable items, are supplied free of charge to people in need.
Insufficiency in one or more of the nutritional elements necessary for health and wellbeing.
A barrier of trees and shrubs that protects against the wind and reduces erosion.
The transformation of land that could once support human life into desert.

The fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) and nuclear fuel. These resources are finite so that as they are used up the supply that remains is reduced. Eventually, these non-renewable resources could become completely exhausted.
Sources of energy such as solar and wind power that are not depleted as they are used.
Wood and charcoal used to supply energy.
A lack of access to modern energy services, particularly electricity.
When a person on a low-income lives in a home that cannot be kept warm at a reasonable cost.
The relative contribution of different energy sources to a country’s energy consumption.
The period of change from heavy reliance on fossil fuels to most of people’s energy needs being supplied by renewable sources of energy.
A study carried out before a development project is undertaken to assess the possible damage to the environment.
The difference between a country’s demand for energy and its ability to satisfy this demand from its own resources.
The uninterrupted availability of energy sources at an affordable price.
The proportion of energy consumption supplied by imports from other countries.
Political relations among nations, particularly relating to disputes about borders, territories and resources.
A large reserve of oil held by a country to tide it over for a few months or so if normal oil supplies are disrupted.
A supply route between energy producers and consumers, which may be through pipelines, shipping routes or electricity cables.
The actions taken by a government to affect the demand for energy as well as the supply of it.
The natural heat found in the Earth’s crust in the form of steam, hot water and hot rock.
Electricity production using the potential energy of water.
Electricity production using sunlight.
Electricty production using the movement of the sea
Electricity production using the power of atomic bonds.
The reduction in unit cost as the scale of an operation increases.
The amount of energy used to produce a given level of output.

An electricity network that uses digital and other advanced technologies to monitor and manage the transport of electricity from all generating sources to meet the varying electricity demands of end users.
An internet-capable device that records the detailed use of household energy.
Reducing the consumption of energy by using it more efficiently.
Energy produced close to the point of consumption.
A generator that produces electricity with an output of less than 50 KW.
A battery system that enables excess energy from renewables to be stored and then released when the power is needed most. (BESS)
A collection of maps usually showing different countries, continents, and physical and human geography.

This term refer to the relationship between the distance on a map and the corresponding real-life distance on the ground, e.g. on a 1:25,000 map, every 4 cm on the map refers to 1 km on the ground, and on a 1:50,000 map every 2 cm on the map refers to 1 km on the ground.
A very simple map, often just an outline, which can then be filled in to show some characteristics of the place in question.
Descriptive or explanatory labelling of a photo or diagram to show the main characteristics/features.
A set of six numbers that identifies the exact location of a place on a map. The first three numbers refer to the eastings and the second three numbers refer to the northings.
A four-figured number that shows the location of a large feature. The first two numbers refer to the eastings and the second two numbers refer to the northings
A type of average; it is the sum of all the values divided by the number of values.
The most common value in a population.
A distribution of a population where there is one clear most common size.
A distribution of a population that has two modes (most frequent values).
The middle value when all the data are placed in ascending or descending order.
A way of expressing ‘inbetween’ numbers. The term comes from the Latin word decimus, meaning tenth.
A fraction is a part of a whole, e.g 1/3 of Borneo’s rainforest has been deforested.
A number or ratio expressed as a fraction of 100 (%).
A method of comparing relative size or proportions, e.g. the area deforested in Borneo compared to the forested areas is 1:2 (i.e. one-third has been deforested and two-thirds remain).
The number that we would normally write, e.g. 281.
A power value that is positive, e.g. 23 = 2 × 2 × 2 = 8.
Powers that have a minus sign
The difference between the highest value and the lowest value.
The number of people needed to support a service, e.g. a small number for a newsagent, a large number for a car salesroom.
A method of selecting individuals for research purposes. In this method, an individual for study is selected at a set interval (e.g. every 10th person)
A method of selecting individuals for research purposes. In this method, there is no set pattern or interval for choosing an individual to participate in the study.

A method of selecting individuals for research purposes. In this method, different subpopulations or groups are created and individuals are selected from these groups using either random or systematic methods.
